summary: This is an FBI 302 report documenting an interview conducted on August 21, 2019, with a Federal Bureau of Prisons psychiatrist regarding her interactions with Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The psychiatrist discusses her suicide risk assessment of Epstein on July 23, 2019, his statements about suicide, and the procedures for inmate monitoring. She notes that knowledge of Epstein changing his will would have been a factor for placing him back on suicide watch.

persons.name: David Carpenter
persons.context: Special Agent with the Office of the Inspector General who participated in the interview of the BOP psychiatrist on August 21, 2019.

persons.name: Amanda Moore
persons.context: Special Agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation who participated in the interview of the BOP psychiatrist on August 21, 2019.

persons.name: Rebekah Donaleski
persons.context: Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who participated in the interview of the BOP psychiatrist on August 21, 2019.

persons.name: Nicholas Roos
persons.context: Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who participated in the interview of the BOP psychiatrist on August 21, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) who was the subject of the psychiatrist's suicide risk assessment on July 23, 2019. He stated he was 'too much of a coward' to commit suicide, that he 'doesn't like pain,' and that suicide goes against his Jewish religion.

persons.name: Michael Owen Gildea Jr
persons.context: The FBI agent who drafted this 302 report on December 18, 2019.

connections.description: Carpenter, as a Special Agent, participated in the interview regarding Epstein's mental state and suicide risk while in custody.
Moore, as an FBI Special Agent, participated in the interview regarding Epstein's mental state and suicide risk while in custody.
Donaleski, as an AUSA for the SDNY, participated in the interview regarding Epstein's mental state as part of the legal proceedings against him.
Roos, as an AUSA for the SDNY, participated in the interview regarding Epstein's mental state as part of the legal proceedings against him.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: A Federal Bureau of Prisons psychiatrist met with inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the MCC and conducted a suicide risk assessment. Epstein reportedly stated he was 'too much of a coward' to commit suicide, that he 'doesn't like pain,' and that suicide goes against his Jewish religion.

events.title: Interview of BOP Psychiatrist
events.description: FBI Special Agents David Carpenter and Amanda Moore, along with AUSAs Rebekah Donaleski and Nicholas Roos, interviewed a Federal Bureau of Prisons psychiatrist regarding her interactions with and assessment of Jeffrey Epstein at the MCC.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York, New York, United States
keyFacts: A BOP psychiatrist conducted a suicide risk assessment on Jeffrey Epstein on July 23, 2019, while he was incarcerated at the MCC.
Epstein told the psychiatrist he was 'too much of a coward' to commit suicide, that he 'doesn't like pain,' and that suicide goes against his Jewish religion.

The psychiatrist stated that if her department had been notified that Epstein changed his will, that would have been a factor warranting a review of his mental state and would likely have resulted in him being placed back on suicide watch.
The psychiatrist advised staff that Epstein would need a cellmate, and routine reviews of his file yielded no factors that would have placed him back on suicide watch.
The interview of the psychiatrist was conducted on August 21, 2019, by FBI and OIG agents and SDNY AUSAs, and the report was drafted on December 18, 2019.
